message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A) which is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder. The finding of an elevated plasma-free metanephrines and a thyroid nodule that stains positive for calcitonin are both associated with MEN2A. The family history of thyroid cancer also supports the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and family history suggest a genetic syndrome, and the presence of a thyroid nodule that stains positive for calcitonin suggests medullary thyroid cancer, which is commonly associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). MEN2 is an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a thyroid nodule, elevated plasma-free metanephrines, and positive calcitonin stain suggest multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). MEN2 is an autosomal dominant genetic syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma and medullary thyroid carcinoma, which are both associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN 2A). MEN 2A is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that only one copy of the gene mutation is necessary to develop the condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest the presence of a medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is associated with MEN 2 syndrome, an autosomal dominant genetic disorder. Patients with MEN 2 have a germline mutation in the RET oncogene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated plasma-free metanephrines, palpable nodule, and positive calcitonin stain suggest a medullary thyroid carcinoma, which is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). MEN2 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms are consistent with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2), an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. This is supported by the family history of thyroid cancer and the finding of calcitonin on fine-needle aspiration. MEN2 is associated with mutations in the RET proto-oncogene.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings suggest multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) type 2A or 2B, which are autosomal dominant genetic syndromes associated with medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma. The presence of a thyroid nodule that stains positive for calcitonin supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical examination suggest a possible diagnosis of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). MEN2 is an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, so option (A) is the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a thyroid nodule and positive calcitonin staining suggest medullary thyroid cancer, which can be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) syndrome. MEN2 is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, meaning that only one copy of the mutated gene from one parent is needed to develop the disease.
